user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA512_256_update:
```c
void
MHD_SHA512_256_update (struct Sha512_256Ctx *ctx,
                       const uint8_t *data,
                       size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */
  uint64_t count_hi; /**< The high part to be moved to another variable */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7
  if (length > ctx->count)
    ctx->count_bits_hi += 1U << 3; /* Value wrap */
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7 */
  count_hi = ctx->count >> 61;
  if (0 != count_hi)
  {
    ctx->count_bits_hi += count_hi;
    ctx->count &= UINT64_C (0x1FFFFFFFFFFFFFFF);
  }

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      sha512_256_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    sha512_256_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7
  if (length > ctx->count)
    ctx->count_bits_hi += 1U << 3; /* Value wrap */
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 7 */
explanation: Fragments reported above are places where code may be effectively unreachable depending on build-time macros or on integer wrap/field values and thus merit investigation for MISRA C Rule 2.1. Other parts of the function (the assertion, the computation of bytes_have, the while loop that processes full blocks, the sha512_256_transform calls, and normal pointer arithmetic/memcpy usage) are standard control-flow constructs that are conditionally executed based on the runtime value of 'length' or 'ctx->count' and are not intrinsically unreachable. In particular: the main while-loop and the memcpy calls inside it are reachable whenever length >= SHA512_256_BLOCK_SIZE; the mhd_assert is a runtime check (or a no-op in non-debug builds) rather than unreachable code; simple assignments and the function prologue are always reachable. Therefore they do not need investigation for unreachable-code concerns.
